title: 107_hr1148
content:
The Act titled "Low-Income and Rural School Program" authorizes a specific program. The Act reserves a portion of funds for awards to Bureau of Indian Affairs schools and grants to State educational agencies for subgrants to local educational agencies. The Secretary allocates funds to State educational agencies based on the number of students served by eligible local educational agencies. Specially qualified agencies can apply directly for grants if a State does not participate in the program. Local educational agencies can apply for grants under this Act by meeting specific criteria, including having a certain percentage of students from low-income families and being located in a designated school community. Specially qualified agencies may also receive direct awards from the Secretary on a competitive basis. Grant funds awarded to local educational agencies or schools under this Act can be used for teacher recruitment and retention, professional development, educational technology, and academic enrichment programs. State educational agencies must distribute funds to local educational agencies based on a competitive basis or a formula tied to student attendance. Administrative costs for the state agency cannot exceed 5% of the grant amount. Applications for grants under this Act are required. Each State educational agency and specially qualified agency must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant under this Act. The application should include specific measurable goals related to student academic achievement and drop-out rates. Additionally, reports are required to track progress. Each State educational agency and specially qualified agency receiving a grant under this Act must provide annual reports to the Secretary. The reports should detail the method of awarding grants, fund usage by local educational agencies and schools, and progress towards meeting goals outlined in the application. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the methods used by State educational agencies to award grants, how funds were used by local educational agencies and schools, and the progress made towards meeting educational goals and objectives. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS.

(1) "Poverty line" refers to the poverty line defined by the Office of Management and Budget, adjusted annually based on family size.
(2) "Specially qualified agency" is an eligible local educational agency in a non-participating state that can directly apply for a grant from the Secretary.
(3) "State" includes the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico.

SEC. 7. PERFORMANCE REVIEW. SEC. 7. Three years after receiving funds, the Secretary will review agency progress towards goals. If funds are deemed inadequate, additional funding may be denied in subsequent years. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations: $125,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding as needed for the following 4 years.
